direction.raw_text: . We're underwater, watching a fat catfish swim along. This is The Beast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Beast's journey takes it past a dangling fish hook, baited with worms. Past a tempting lure, sparkling in the sun. Past a swiping bear claw. The Beast isn't worried.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) There are some fish that cannot be caught. It's not that they're faster or stronger than other fish. They're just touched by something extra. Call it luck. Call it grace. One such fish was The Beast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) By the time I was born, he was already a legend. He'd taken more hundred- dollar lures than any fish in Alabama. Some said that fish was the ghost of Henry Walls, a thief who'd drowned in that river 60 years before. Others claimed he was a lesser dinosaur, left over from the Cretaceous period.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: listens wide-eyed as his father EDWARD BLOOM, 40's and handsome, tells the story. In every gesture, Edward is bigger than life, describing each detail with absolute conviction.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't put any stock into such speculation or superstition. All I knew was I'd been trying to catch that fish since I was a boy no bigger than you. (closer) And on the day you were born, that was the day I finally caught him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A few years later, and Will sits with the other INDIAN GUIDES as Edward continues telling the story to the tribe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward points to his wedding band, glinting in the firelight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward slips his ring off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: While the other boys are rapt with attention, Will looks bored. He's heard this story before.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now, I'd tried everything on it: worms, lures, peanut butter, peanut butter-and-cheese. But on that day I had a revelation: if that fish was the ghost of a thief, the usual bait wasn't going to work. I would have to use something he truly desired.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (confused) Your finger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I tied my ring to the strongest line they made -- strong enough to hold up a bridge, they said, if just for a few minutes -- and I cast upriver.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward is chatting up Will's pretty DATE to the homecoming dance. She is enjoying the story, but also the force of Edward's charisma. He's hypnotizing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The Beast jumped up and grabbed it before the ring even hit the water. And just as fast, he snapped clean through that line.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: now 17 with braces, is fuming and ready to leave. His mother SANDRA -- from whom he gets his good looks and practicality -- stands with him at the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You can see my predicament. My wedding ring, the symbol of fidelity to my wife, soon to be the mother of my child, was now lost in the gut of an uncatchable fish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (low but insistent) Make him stop. His mother pats him sympathetically, then adjusts his tie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will regards his father with exasperated contempt.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What did you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I followed that fish up-river and down-river for three days and three nights, until I finally had him boxed in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With these two hands, I reached in and snatched that fish out of the river. I looked him straight in the eye. And I made a remarkable discovery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: now 28, sits with his gorgeous bride JOSEPHINE. This is their wedding reception, crowded with their friends and family. They should be joyful, but Will is furious. Edward has the floor, ostensibly for a toast. The room is cozy and drunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Over near the doorway, we spot Sandra, just returned from the restrooms. She looks gorgeous. She couldn't be any happier if this were her own wedding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will can't take any more. Josephine tries to hold him back, but he gets up and leaves. Edward doesn't even notice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he leaves, Will mutters in perfect unison with his father -- EDWARD AND WILL We were part of the same equation. Will reaches the door, where his mother intercepts him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will can't articulate his anger. He just leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He focuses his words on Sandra. This story is -- and has always been -- about her more than anyone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This fish, the Beast. The whole time we were calling it a him, when in fact it was a her. It was fat with eggs, and was going to lay them any day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, I was in a situation. I could gut that fish and get my ring back, but doing so I would be killing the smartest catfish in the Ashton River, soon to be mother of a hundred others.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did I want to deprive my soon-to-be- born son the chance to catch a fish like this of his own? This lady fish and I, well, we had the same destiny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Honey, it's still your night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, you may well ask, since this lady fish wasn't the ghost of a thief, why did it strike so quick on gold when nothing else would attract it? (closer; he holds up his ring) That was the lesson I learned that day, the day my son was born.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes, the only way to catch an uncatchable woman is to offer her a wedding ring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: from the crowd. Edward motions for Sandra to get up here with him. As she crosses, we can see that thirty years of marriage has not lessened their affection for each other. As they kiss, Edward tweaks her chin a special little way. The crowd APPLAUDS. Edward toasts the happy couple. Josephine covers well for her absent husband, a smile as warm as summer. Edward downs his champagne in a gulp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We come into the middle of an argument on the sidewalk. Occasional PASSERSBY take notice, especially as it gets more heated. Both men are a little drunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long beat, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will won't let him get the last word.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What, a father's not allowed to talk about his son?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disbelieving) I am a footnote in that story. I am the context for your great adventure. Which never happened! Incidentally! You were selling novelty products in Wichita the day I was born.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) Jesus Christ.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Friend of yours? Did you help him out of a bind?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Will. Everyone likes that story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No Dad, they don't. I do not like the story. Not anymore, not after a thousand times. I know all the punchlines, Dad. I can tell them as well as you can. (closer) For one night, one night in your entire life, the universe does not revolve around Edward Bloom. It revolves around me and my wife. How can you not understand that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (low) Sorry to embarrass you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're embarrassing yourself, Dad. You just don't see it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ON Edward. Fine. A hand to wave, enough of you. He walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON Will, still fuming with righteous anger. It's then we FREEZE FRAME.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) After that night, I didn't speak to my father again for three years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .P. NEWSROOM (PARIS) - DAY A typically busy day. On hold with the phone cradled under an ear, Will sorts through a bundle of mail dropped on his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's put back on hold. Returning to the mail, he finds a hand-addressed envelope. Rips it open.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (without pauses) William Bloom with the Associated Press if I could just...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) We communicated indirectly I guess. In her letters and Christmas cards, my mother would write for both of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: At the table, Sandra talks on the phone while Edward fixes a sandwich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward takes a seat, starting to eat his sandwich.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) When I'd call, Mom would say that Dad was out driving. Or swimming in the pool.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: True to form, we never talked about our not talking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sandra stands by the window, watching as...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: [CONTINUOUS] Edward swims laps in the family pool. He's born to the water.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) The truth is, I didn't see anything of myself in my father, and I don't think he saw anything of himself in me. We were like strangers who knew each other very well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward stares intently into the water, a lion in wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We LOOK DOWN at the river, where Edward's reflection is caught in the dark water. As the water ripples past, something changes. Sure enough, as we LOOK UP again, it's a younger EDWARD BLOOM, 20's, staring into the water. He's not just handsome, not just charming. It's as if all the forces of the natural world had conspired to create him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, this Edward thrusts both hands into the water, grabbing hold of
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) In telling the story of my father's life, it's impossible to separate the fact from the fiction, the man from the myth. The best I can do is to tell it the way he told me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) It doesn't always make sense, and most of it never happened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . He brings the catfish up to his face. Looks it right in the eye. A beat, then the Beast spits out Edward's gold ring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smiling, Edward takes the ring, then throws the Beast back into the water with a splash.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) But that's what kind of story this is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HOSPITAL ROOM - DAY Young Dr. Bennett stands between the Wife's legs. She's flustered and sweating, but the doctor has a comforting bedside manner...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, we hear a POP as a slimy mass of human being rockets into the doctor's unprepared hands. Bennett tries to hold tight, but the infant is slippery like a fish. It shoots up into air. The NURSES and the Husband try to grab the baby, but no one can hold it. As the newborn sails upward TOWARDS CAMERA, we can see a GIGGLING SMILE on its face. As it falls, the newborn knocks over a tray, which provides it a ramp to slide right out of the room. Everyone races after it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT Now, Mrs. Bloom, I'll need you to give me one good push. On three. One...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bursting through the doors -- YOUNG DR. BENNETT Grab that baby!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: finally scoops up the slippery baby. Everyone lets out a collective sigh of relief.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) My father's birth would set the pace for his unlikely life. No longer than most men's, but larger. And as strange as his stories got, the endings were always the most surprising of all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (PRESENT) DAY Over the sound of rain, a phone RINGS on a chair. By the tone of the ring, we know we're not in the U.S. -- it has that insistent European sound. As it keeps RINGING, we look to see the apartment is mostly empty, just a few half-unpacked boxes. A cradle is still in its carton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in the lock. LAUGHTER in the hallway. The door swings open to reveal a drenched Will (29) carrying four sacks of groceries, the bottoms collapsing from the rain. His wife Josephine (28) pushes past him to get the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will begins stripping out of his wet clothes, each layer unleashing a new drizzle. He plays it up, trying to get a reaction out of Josephine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands the phone to Will, concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Half-stripped, Will takes the phone. This won't be good news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Josephine takes off her rain coat, we see she is very, very pregnant. She listens carefully to Will's side of the conversation, trying to gauge how bad the news is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He covers the mouthpiece. Looks over to Josephine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Allo oui?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) Yes, he's here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's your mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) Hi. Uh-huh. Uh-huh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does Dr. Bennett say? Okay. No, sure, let me talk to him. I'll wait.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's more than they thought. They're going to stop chemo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You need to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Probably tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a simple fact) I'm going with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As the plane continues boarding, a STEWARDESS recites the welcome spiel in French. Will has a window seat in coach. Josephine sits beside him, putting on hand lotion. Taking his hands, she rubs the excess into him. There's an effortless intimacy between them. She can pinpoint what he's feeling before he can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hours later, and the lights are dimmed. Most of the PASSENGERS are asleep, including Josephine. Her head is propped against Will's shoulder, her hands tucked under her belly. Will watches her sleep, brushing back her hair. A beat, then he notices a BORED BOY in the next row over. Off the glow of the reading light, the boy is using his hands to cast shadows on the seat back. The kid is pretty good, making a convincing bird, a passable monkey, and finally a dog. We PUSH IN on the silhouettes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Focusing on the final shadow, we...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S., PRELAP) So which one's it gonna be? The Monkey in the Barn, the Dog in the Road?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...come to find Edward making the shapes. Will (6) sits in his pajamas on the floor next to him. The endtable lamp lies between them, its shade off to cast big shadows on the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward looks around for a beat, seeing if his wife is in earshot. He then leans in, complicitous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will smiles, excited to hear the forbidden story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward holds up his hand, counting the names on his fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As his hand moves past the light, we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : A flashlight SWEEPS past. We are...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The one about the witch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your mom says I can't tell you that one anymore. You get nightmares.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not scared.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Neither was I. At first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This all happened in the swamp outside of Ashton. Kids weren't supposed to go out in the swamp, on account of the snakes and spiders and quicksand that would swallow you up before you could even scream. But there were five of us out there that night: Me, Ruthie, Wilbur Freely, and the Price Brothers, Don and Zacky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not a one of us knew what was in store.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The night is WHIRRING and BREATHING, alive. The moon hangs low, casting long shadows. Five kids walk past in silhouette. Four have flashlights on. The fifth keeps tripping, crashing into YOUNG EDWARD (10).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Red-headed ZACKY PRICE is 10. His brother DON PRICE is 12, and a lot bigger than the others. DON PRICE Then why'd you bring it?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Zacky, turn your flashlight on!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't got any batteries!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to be in the swamp with a witch and no flashlight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: also 10, is the black asthmatic son of a sharecropper. Redheaded RUTHIE MACKLIN, 8, is happy just to be there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is it true she got a glass eye?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I heard she got it from Gypsies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's a Gypsy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your momma's a Gypsy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your momma's a bitch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You shouldn't swear. There's ladies present.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Damn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Screw.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering) Turn off your flashlights! She'll see 'em.

direction.raw_text: UP behind the kids, we find ourselves at the gates of...

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Now, it's common knowledge that most towns of a certain size have a witch, if only to eat misbehaving children and the occasional puppy who wanders into her yard. Witches use those bones to cast spells and curses that make the land infertile. We PULL BACK, and BACK, revealing more of the Gothically creepy house: its broken windows, strangling vines, and eerie gargoyles half-buried in the dirt. Even bats are afraid to fly over it. In the moonlight, the house is especially sinister. Who knows what is lurking in the shadows?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We finally come to the kids, staring in through the gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward looks back at the spooky house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands Zacky his flashlight, then starts climbing the gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward drops down on the far side of the gate. Truth be told, Edward is scared, but he forges ahead anyway. Wilbur looks to Ruthie, and they're in complete agreement. They get the hell out of there. Zacky would run too, but Don holds him by the collar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Yet of the all the witches in Alabama, there was one who was the most feared. For she had one glass eye, which was said to contain mystical powers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hear if you look right at it, you can see how you're gonna die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's bull-s-h-i-t, that is. She's not even a real witch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're so sure, why don't you go in and get that eye? I heard she keeps it in a box on her nighttable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or are you too scared?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll go in right now and get that eye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, I will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, you do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, I'm doing it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Edward, don't!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She'll make soap out of you! (to Ruthie) That's what she does, she makes soap out of people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward curves around the tall bushes that hide the front door. Anything could jump out of them. He steps on the porch. The boards SQUEAL and CREAK, but he continues on. A cat SCREAMS OUT from a broken wicker rocker. Catching his breath, Edward reaches the front door. The doorknob is ancient brass, two projections that look like horns. Yet Edward extends his hand, reaching closer and closer before he finally
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Impossibly fast, the door opens, revealing an OLD WOMAN with a patch over her left eye. She looks like she's been dead for years, but too stubborn to lie down.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calm and straightforward) Ma'am, my name is Edward Bloom, and there's some folks'd like to see your eye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Zacky and Don Price wait for Edward, each moment more convinced he's already dead. But suddenly, he's back at the gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Old Woman steps out of the shadows behind Edward, flipping up her eye patch. When their flashlight beam hits her left eye, it shines with a hellish glow. We RUSH IN on Zacky, who is paralyzed by what he sees.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You get the eye?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I brought it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dubious) Let's see it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: An OLD MAN -- Zacky -- stands on a wobbly stepladder, changing a lightbulb. Suddenly, the ladder gives way and he falls. Dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We RUSH IN on Don Price.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty-year old Don Price falls face-forward on the tile, face mushed in the grout. Very much dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don and Zacky both tremble with fear. The latter has tears in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The brothers suddenly bolt. Still standing next to the Old Woman, Edward smiles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I saw how I was gonna die. I was old, and I fell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wasn't old at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward helps her back inside. He could leave now, but curiosity gets the better of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Old Woman turns to him slightly, still not facing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Old Woman smiles a little, a crooked grin of broken teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Old Woman turns leaning her face right in front of his. And on a silent count of one, two, three -- Edward looks into The Eye. This time we don't cut. Instead, we HOLD ON Edward as he witnesses his death. He stares transfixed, perplexed and amused. Whatever he sees, it's not as dire as the other boys. His future has something strange in store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Old Woman nods. Still a little overwhelmed, Edward turns and leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Edward leaves, the door swings SHUT on its own.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I was thinking about death and all. About seeing how you're gonna die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, on one hand, if dying was all you thought about, it could kind of screw you up. But it could kind of help you, couldn't it? Because you'd know that everything else you can survive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess I'm saying, I'd like to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh. That's how I go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) From that moment on, I no longer feared death. And for that, I was as good as immortal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (PRESENT) DAY The front door opens to reveal Will and Josephine on the porch with their bags. REVERSE to Will's mother Sandra (53), surprised and a little annoyed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat. Starting over...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans in and hugs her. She surrenders, squeezing her son tight. Will and his mother are cut from the same cloth -- strong-willed but practical. They've always been close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That hug finished, Sandra pushes past her son to her daughter- in-law. Seeing the size of her belly -- SANDRA You shouldn't have flown. But... They hug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not flattery. It's the truth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Josephine squeezes past, a smile to her husband -- be nice. Will heads back to the rental car to retrieve luggage. Sandra follows him. Coming down the driveway, we get to see the house for the first time: an older suburban home, three bedrooms, big for the neighborhood, and nicely grown into the lot. KIDS are playing on the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heading back to the house...

dialogue.raw_text: It's good to see you. You look beautiful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Down the hall on the right. The door sticks. You have to really pull it.

dialogue.raw_text: How much time does he have left?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sandra is pouring iced tea for Will and Josephine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . JULIUS BENNETT (85) enters from the foyer, still winded from coming down the stairs. He was the town's first Black physician. He's still the town's best physician.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He judges her belly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans close to her, whispering in her ear...
