direction.raw_text: She smiles, surprised but not doubting. Will looks over -- what did he say? Josephine shakes her head. Back to the main subject...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And in the silence that follows, a lot is said. It wasn't the upbeat reply Sandra was hoping for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A moment of awkwardness -- everyone here knows they haven't spoken in years. Sandra hands Will a squat can of Ensure from the case on the counter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT Will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Bennett. It's good to see you. (they shake) My wife, Josephine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT A pleasure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT You're seven months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impressed) To the day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT It's a boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't think he looks any worse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT No. I would say he's the same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I see him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT Absolutely. Be good for you to talk to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get him to drink one of these. He won't, but tell him he has to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Coming out from the kitchen, Will slowly climbs the stairs. They CREAK with every step. The wall is filled with family photos, happier times. Most of the pictures are of Will, starting when he was an infant and ending at his wedding. As he climbs the stairs, we can see him growing up with every step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A crack of sunlight spills around the half-open door at the end of the hallway. Will walks towards it, running a hand along the wallpaper. Almost at the door, he stops for a beat. Gets his breath. Then goes inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward Bloom, 61, lies asleep on the bed. Although he's not the vibrant man we've seen before, it's not as bad we feared. The illness has been quick, and left him largely intact. There are no I.V.'s, no monitors, nothing. Coming up to the bed -- WILL Dad? Edward cracks open an eye, a beat before he focuses. He tries to say something, but no words come out. He looks over at a pitcher on the nightstand. Will pours him a glass of water, helping him hold it to his parched lips. Finished, Edward sets down the glass by himself. A very long, tense beat. Will almost speaks again to fill the silence. Finally...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will doesn't rise to the challenge. A beat, then he remembers the can of Ensure. Holds it up. Edward recoils.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat, then Edward rolls his eyes. Fine. Will cracks open the can, finding a straw on the nightstand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward slurps down as much of the Ensure as he can stand, then pushes the can away. He swallows with difficulty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward gives a wry smile. He walked into that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will won't commit to Edward's assessment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward LAUGHS a little, which becomes a COUGH. The HACKING escalates until another drink of water gets it under control. It's not clear whether any of this was an act to keep from talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He didn't mean for that to sound so pointed. Taking the half- empty Ensure, Will gets up to go. He's at the door when...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles at his joke.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You -- (he points)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: are in for a surprise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Am I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Having a kid changes everything. I mean, there's the diapers and the burping and the midnight feedings...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you do any of that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but I hear it's terrible. Then you spend years trying to corrupt and mislead this child, fill its head with nonsense and still it turns out perfectly fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think I'm up for it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You learned from the best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just drink half the can. I'll tell her you drank the whole thing. Everyone wins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: People needn't worry so much. It's not my time yet. This isn't how I go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Truly. I saw it in The Eye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Old Lady by the swamp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She was a witch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, she was old and probably senile. Maybe schizophrenic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw my death in that eye. And this is not how it happens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So how does it happen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Surprise ending. Wouldn't want to ruin it for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There was this panhandler who used to stop me every morning when I came out of this coffee shop near the office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And every day I gave him a quarter. Every day. Then I got sick and was out for a couple of weeks. And when I went back there, you know what he said?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did he say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You owe me three-fifty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: True story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When did you ever work in an office?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a lot you don't know about me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your mother was worried we wouldn't talk again. And look at us. We're talking fine. We're storytellers, both of us. I speak mine out, you write yours down. Same thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dad, I'm hoping we can talk about some things while I'm here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean, while I'm here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd just like to know the true versions of things. Events. Stories. You.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your mother hasn't been keeping up the pool. If you wanted to you could...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know where the chemicals are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I used to do it when you were gone, remember? I used to do it a lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was never much for being at home, Will. It's too confining. And this, here. Being stuck in bed. Dying is the worst thing that ever happened to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought you weren't dying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said this isn't how I go. The last part is much more unusual. Trust me on that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Shutting the door behind himself, Will drinks the rest of the Ensure himself. Edward was right. It tastes horrible. Heading for the stairs, Will walks past an open door. As he leaves frame, we STAY BEHIND to look inside...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: [FLASHBACK] ...where an eight-year old Will is propped up in bed, his face covered with chicken pox and pink calamine lotion. He's showing Edward how many bumps there are on his arm.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Bennett says I'm going to have to be home for a week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's nothing. I once had to stay in bed for three years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you have chicken pox?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wearing a white shirt and tie, YOUNG EDWARD -- still about 10 -- sings "Down to the River My Lord" along with the CONGREGATION. His voice is high and thin, but he gives it his all. Suddenly, his voice CRACKS and DROPS a half-octave. And then another. His friends Wilbur Freeley and Ruthie look over, wondering what's wrong. Embarrassed, Edward just keeps SINGING, trying to follow along with the baritone part. He pulls at his collar. Then pulls again, his face getting red. Starting to panic, he loosens his tie. He's starting to undo the collar button when it POPS off by itself. Two more buttons fly off. One hits a CHUBBY WOMAN in the neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As we watch, Edward's pant cuffs rise inch by inch -- that's how fast he's growing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Truth is, no one quite knew what was wrong. Most times, a person grows up gradually. I found myself in a hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Young Edward lies in bed, his limbs connected to various pulleys and levers to support his weight. He has a dozen encyclopedias around him, and another dozen on the floor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) My muscles couldn't keep up with my bones, and my bones couldn't keep up with my body's ambition. So I spent the better part of three years confined to my bed, with the World Book Encyclopedia being my only means of exploration. I had made it all the way to the "G's," hoping to find an answer to my gigantificationism, when I uncovered an article about the common goldfish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : The encyclopedia article, complete with drawings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Young Edward thinks this through.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) "Kept in a small bowl, the goldfish will remain small. With more space, the fish can grow double, triple, or quadruple its size."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) It occurred to me then, that perhaps the reason for my growth was that I was intended for larger things. After all, a giant man can't have an ordinary-sized life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The CRACK of a bat announces the game-winning home run. The crowd CHEERS the swing, and especially the batter as he rounds the bases. Although we've seen him briefly before, this is our first real exposure to GROWN-UP EDWARD, who we'll follow from roughly the ages of 18 to 30.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) As soon as my bones had settled in their adult configuration, I set upon my plan to make a bigger place for myself in Ashton.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S: Football hero Edward leads his team to victory. On the sidelines, a PRETTY GIRL admits the name of her secret love:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other GIRLS SQUEAL in agreement. Don Price looks over, glowers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Edward Bloom!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : A lawnmower ROARS along the grass. We LOOK UP to see who's pushing it, but it's not Edward. It's one of his teenage EMPLOYEES. Edward is back at the truck, which is painted to read, "Bloom Landscaping." He has workers on every lawn. He signs an autograph for an ADMIRING CUB SCOUT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward takes an impossible shot at the buzzer from the other end of the court. Naturally, he makes it, winning the game. As the crowd goes wild for Edward, Don Price is the only teammate who doesn't mob him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward carries a dog out of a burning house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward wins a blue ribbon for his invention, a machine labelled "Perpetual Motion." He and the JUDGE pose for a photograph. A FLASH. Pissed, Don Price throws his crappy lima bean plants in the trash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A dashingly handsome Edward leads the CAST out for a curtain call. He's the star of the show. Off to the side, we see Don Price is the ass-end of a horse costume. Edward soaks in his applause, smiling and gracious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward accepts his diploma. The PRINCIPAL hugs him tight.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I was the biggest thing Ashton had ever seen. Until one day, a stranger arrived.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As two FARMERS shake their heads, we REVERSE to a show a massive hole punched through the side of a barn. It's roughly the shape of man, but no human could be that large.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two fat ewes look up, a shadow falling across them. They BLEAT in panic as
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: reach in and scoop them up. Their protests continue as they're carried away, one under each arm. We still haven't seen the full stranger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of about 50 have gathered, many of them with shotguns. Amid the crowd we see Don Price.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Agreement from the crowd. And then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone turns to see who said that. The crowd parts to reveal none other than Edward Bloom. Don Price glowers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He ate an entire cornfield!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He ate my dog!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: GUN TOTER If you ain't gonna stop him Mayor, we will!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't have mob violence in this town. Now, has someone tried talking to him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't reason with 'im!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a monster!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) I'll do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll talk to him. See if I can get him to move on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Son, that creature could crush you without trying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Trust me, he'll have to try.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward climbs up the last bit of the steep hillside, reaching the mouth of a cave. Outside, buzzards squabble over the remains of the giant's feast: broken barrels, bones picked clean. In his most serious voice, Edward calls out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From deep in a cave, a thunderous voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The giant's voice has such force, it blows Edward's hair back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat, then we hear a RUMBLE, like a train coming. Edward braces himself, fists ready for a fight, if that's what it's going to take. As the RUMBLE gets louder, the ground starts to shake. Even Edward starts to worry. Just how big is this guy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward picks up a stone, ready to play David to Goliath. Then suddenly, the giant bursts forth. Hunched over, he slams into a stunned Edward, knocking him halfway down the hill.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name is Edward Bloom! I want to talk to you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not going anywhere until you show yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Armed with the foreknowledge of my own death, I knew the giant couldn't kill me. All the same, I preferred to keep my bones unbroken.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is bigger than any man you've ever seen. Not just tall, but massive. He's completely feral, with a beard to his elbow and skin scratched and blistered. What remains of his clothes are ragged and muddy. God knows what's living in his matted hair. Karl leans over Edward, blocking the sun. Edward throws his rock, but it just bounces off. The giant didn't even notice it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward ponders the best response, settling on...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl's eyes narrow, confused. Edward stands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward closes his eyes, hands at his side, ready to be eaten. Karl just stares at him, not sure what to do. After a beat, Edward opens his eyes a tiny bit, just to see what the giant is doing. Relieved to see he's not licking his chops -- EDWARD Look, I can't go back. I'm a human sacrifice. If I go back, everyone will think I'm a coward. And I'd rather be dinner than a coward. Karl sits down with a BOOM, dejected.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reaching up, Edward shoves his hand into Karl's mouth. But the giant spits it back out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that's the sad truth. Karl is less a monster than a freak -- a giant man, but in the end, just a man. Edward takes a seat beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Circling behind them, we look down at Ashton -- a tiny town in a tiny valley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl smiles, but then it fades. A certain sad suspicion -- KARL You're just trying to get me to leave, aren't you? That's why they sent you here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl thinks a moment. Then -- KARL Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They shake on it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why are you here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you can eat me. The town decided to send a human sacrifice, and I volunteered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My arms are a little stringy, but there's some good eating on my legs. I mean, I'd be tempted to eat them myself. (beat) So I guess, just, if you could get it over with quick. Because I'm not much for pain, really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, start with my hand. It'll be an appetizer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to eat you. I don't want to eat anybody. It's just I get so hungry. I'm too big.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you ever think maybe you're not too big? Maybe this town's just too small. I mean, look at it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hardly two stories in the whole place. Now I've heard in real cities, they've got buildings so tall you can't even see the tops of 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wouldn't lie to you. And they've got all-you-can-eat buffets. You can eat a lot, can't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So why are you wasting your time in a small town? You're a big man. You should be in the big city.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's your name, Giant?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Karl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mine's Edward. And truthfully, I do want you to leave, Karl. But I want to leave with you. (closer) You think this town is too small for you, well, it's too small for a man of my ambition. I can't see staying here a day longer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't like it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love every square inch of it. But I can feel the edges closing in on me. A man's life can only grow to a certain size in a place like this. (beat) So what do you say? Join me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now first, we gotta get you ready for the city.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: , Karl cuts his hair with hedge clippers, while Edward cuts up a surplus army tent to make him a shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spirits buoyed by the high school MARCHING BAND, all the good CITIZENS of Ashton are gathered to see off Edward and Karl. There's a few tears amid the familiar faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward ducks a bit so the Mayor can put the key around his neck. The crowd CHEERS. And with that, Edward and Karl start walking, waving as they go. Only DON PRICE, smoking on the corner, isn't sad to see Edward go. He crushes his cigarette under his heel. He wishes he could crush Edward. Many of the townfolk come onto the street to hug Edward or shake his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the crowd parts, he finds himself face to face with
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (loudly, for the crowd) Edward Bloom, first son of Ashton, it's with a heavy heart we see you go. But take with you this Key to the City, and know that any time you want to come back, all our doors are open to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) That afternoon as I left Ashton, everyone seemed to have advice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Find yourself a nice girl! Don't trust anyone in Kentucky! Watch your pride, Edward Bloom!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) But there was one person whose counsel I held above all others.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . The ruckus slows and quiets, as if a strange spell has been cast. She motions for Edward to lean down, so she can whisper something to him. Although we're VERY CLOSE, we can't hear her voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The advice only succeeds in confusing Edward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward and Karl keep walking. The Old Woman shuffles off, somehow knowing her advice will go unheeded.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) She said that the biggest fish in the river gets that way by never being caught.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the Old Woman) Okay. Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did she say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Beats me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We TILT UP from the road to reveal Edward and Karl walking out of Ashton. Each wears a backpack with all his earthly possessions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward and Karl come to a bend, where the paved road veers left and an overgrown dirt road runs straight. The old road is blocked with signs and warnings of danger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl looks at the dirt road, wary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little paranoid...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl perks up, even though it means more for him to carry.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) There were two roads out of Ashton, a new one which was paved, and an older one that wasn't. People didn't use the old road anymore, and it had developed the reputation of being haunted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Since I had no intention of ever returning to Ashton, this seemed as good a time as any to find out what lay down that old road.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know anyone's who's taken it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That poet, Norther Winslow did. He was going to Paris, France. He must have liked it, because no one ever heard from him again. (beat) Tell you what. You take the other way and I'll cut through here. Meet you on the far side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not trying to run away?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just to be sure, you can take my pack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The road is overgrown, but not altogether creepy. The sun is still shining, and the birds still CHIRPING. Spinning the Key to the City, Edward WHISTLES, because it's a day meant for whistling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The road has narrowed to a rough path. Spikes of sunlight break through the thick canopy, catching particles in the air. Still, Edward WHISTLES. Coming around a bend, his PITCH DROPS as he sees thick, thorny vines growing across the path. He stops. For the first time, he realizes the birds have stopped singing. The forest is dead quiet. He looks back the way he came. It's tempting to go back. It would be easier to go back. But Edward presses on. He carefully steps through the thorns. His trouser legs catch on the barbs. We can hear the fabric TEAR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A scratched and sweaty Edward waves off various STINGING BUGS flying at him, finally whipping off his hat to swat at them. Just then a CAWING crow swoops down and grabs the hat right out of his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops his swearing, but grabs a rock and throws it. The stone ricochets off a tree and into a BEE'S NEST. The swarm roars out. Edward high-tails it, each step still precarious.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You stupid sonofa...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: [LATER] Edward is bruised, battered and bee-stung. A half-broken sign lies in the road. Edward picks it up. Reads it:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure enough, up ahead he sees the path is overgrown with thick cobwebs, heavy from the rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward tosses the sign and forges ahead, into the spiderwebs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) There comes a point where a reasonable man will swallow his pride and admit he's made a terrible mistake. The truth is, I was never a reasonable man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what I recalled of Sunday School was that the more difficult something became, the more rewarding it was in the end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward emerges from the forest, brushing the last cobwebs off and shaking the spiders from his shirt. One is stuck in his sleeve, and he has to dance to get it out. Even then, he still keeps twitching, convinced another one is left behind. At his feet, the gravel road has returned, smooth and dusty and comforting. Ahead lies a tiny one-street town -- smaller even than Ashton -- with powerlines emerging from the woods to feed it. Dangling from the line above he sees two dozen pairs of shoes, their laces tied together. He passes a sign that reads "Welcome To Spectre!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a main street with stores on each side: Cole's Pharmacy, Talbot's Five and Dime, Al's Country Store. Everything is old, but this isn't a ghost town. In fact, there's a group of about 20 CITIZENS spilling out to see Edward approach. Most are smiling. There are even a few tears of joy. What's more, all of these people are barefoot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A forty-year old man named BEAMEN comes out of the seed store to greet Edward. Friendly but a little drunk, he's the closest thing the town has to a mayor. He's carrying a clipboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beamen checks the clipboard. Not finding the name, he flips forward a few pages. Still looking...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still confused...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A helpful woman named MILDRED chimes in:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beamen's daughter JENNY (8) hides behind her father, peering around to look at the handsome stranger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He didn't mean it as a joke, but for some reason, everyone's laughing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Friend!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Welcome to ya. What's your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Edward Bloom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bloom like a flower?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Here! Right here. Edward Bloom. We weren't expecting you yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were expecting me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must have taken a shortcut.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did. It nearly killed me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mmm-hmm. Life'll do that to you. And truthfully, the long way is easier, but it's longer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Much longer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you're here now, and that's what matters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is this place?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The town of Spectre. Best kept secret in Alabama. Says here you're from Ashton, right? Last person we had from Ashton was Norther Winslow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The poet? What ever happened to him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's still here. Let me buy you a drink. I'll tell you all about it. Hell, I'll have him tell you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I've gotta meet somebody. I'm already running late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Son, I already told you. You're early.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sitting at the kitchen table, Edward takes a second slice of apple pie. He and Beamen are joined by NORTHER WINSLOW (30), who fancies himself a cultured artist, though he's never left the state.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now tell me if that isn't the best pie you ever ate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It truly is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Young Jenny is stealthily untying the laces on Edward's shoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, Jenny YANKS OFF Edward's shoes. She races for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He chases after her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Everything here tastes better. Even the water is sweet. Never gets too hot, too cold, too humid. At night the wind goes through the trees and you'd swear there was a whole symphony out there, playing just for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As she runs, Jenny ties Edward's laces together. Reaching the edge of town, she tosses the shoes up and around the power line -- a perfect throw. There's no way he's ever getting them down. The gathered citizens of Spectre CHEER for Edward, who is confused and overwhelmed. The women hug him. Men shake his hand. Still focused on his shoes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The townsfolk continue to congratulate Edward... EDWARD (V.O.) Sometimes in a dream, you'll visit places that seem instantly familiar, filled with friends you've never met.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wait! I need those!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is no softer ground than town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That rhymes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is our poet laureate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward sits with Norther Winslow. The fireflies are out. Thousands of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Norther hands him his noteboook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Norther grabs his notebook back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Norther doesn't answer. Just goes back to his notebook.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) A man might travel his entire life and never find a place so inviting. My journey had scarcely begun, and I had arrived.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been working on this poem for 12 years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a lot of expectation. I don't want to disappoint my fans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's only three lines long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is why you don't show work in progress.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Norther, do you ever regret not making it to Paris?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't imagine any place better than here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a poet. You oughta be able to. And maybe if you'd seen more, you could.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: By the light of the full moon, Edward soaks his feet in the water, trying to make sense of it all. The Key to the City dangles around his neck. He stares at himself in the reflection. He smiles. It's then that a WOMAN emerges at the far side of the river. No telling where she came from -- she must have been swimming underwater. We never see her face. She stands in the river with her bare back to Edward, squeezing the water out of her golden hair, oblivious to his presence. Edward is breathless. It's the first woman he's seen in her natural state, and he doesn't dare move lest he frighten her away. Then he sees the snake. It's a cottonmouth, has to be. It leaves a break in the water, its small reptilian head aiming for her flesh. There's no decision to be made. On pure instinct, Edward dives in. He swims as hard as can,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: just as it's about to strike. The woman dives back underwater, understandably terrified that a man is coming at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the splashing subsides, Edward looks at what he holds in his hands. Which isn't a snake at all, but rather a common stick. And a non-threatening one at that. While Edward ponders his mistake, he looks around to discover that the Girl in the River is gone. He never even saw her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward keeps expecting her to surface, somewhere, but she never does. He stands alone in the river, wondering what tricks his eyes are playing on him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No, it's okay! I got it. I got the snake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait! I'm sorry. Hello?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CONTINUOUS A GIRL'S VOICE (O.S.) There's leeches in there! Edward looks to the bank, where young Jenny Hill is watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Embarrassed to admit it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Given the day he's had so far, Edward isn't inclined to follow up on the issue. He starts to wade back to the bank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward climbs up onto the shore, completely drenched. He pulls up his pant legs to reveal three shiny leeches clinging to his skin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to work pulling them off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did you see that woman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did she look like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, she... uh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was she nekkid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (matter-of-fact) It's not a woman, it's a fish. No one ever catches her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fish looks diff'rent to diff'rent people. My daddy said it looked like the coon dog he had when he was kid, back from the dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shoot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward and Jenny walk back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eager to get off this subject...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How old are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eighteen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm eight. That means when I'm eighteen, you'll be 28. And when I'm 28, you'll only be 38.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a little wary) You're pretty good at arithmetic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And when I'm 38, you'll be 48. And that's not much difference at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure is a lot now, though, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Edward and Jenny approach Main Street, they find "downtown" has been transformed. Lanterns and streamers hang on cables across the street, and a small stage has been built at one end to hold FIDDLERS. The whole town is there in celebration of its newest citizen, Edward Bloom. Before he can protest, two WOMEN have grabbed him by the arms, pulling him in to dance with them. The resulting dance number seems both choreographed and complete chaos. From FARMER to BAKER'S WIFE, everyone wants to dance with Edward, who finds himself tossed around like a stick caught in a whirlpool. Still, he's having a blast. Jenny grabs both his hands, and they spin wildly. Beamen plucks his LAUGHING daughter away to dance with her. Then Mildred cuts in to dance with Edward. It's hard to hear over the MUSIC.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward stops dancing. A beat, then he heads for the edge of the crowd. Beamen is there, with Jenny on his shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And with that, Edward walks down Main Street. The townspeople stop dancing, disbelieving, some shaking their heads. Poor Edward Bloom's gone crazy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jenny runs to him. She'd tackle him if she could.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not good enough, but it will have to do. Edward keeps walking. EXT. THE DARK FOREST - NIGHT VARIOUS SHOTS: Edward negotiates the thorns in his bare feet. It's horrible. Almost unendurable. And then it gets worse. The trees ahead are moving. At first, it just seems to be the wind blowing the branches, but as we hear the wood CRACKING and GROANING, there's no mistaking it: they're trying to block him. Snake-like WHITE ROOTS shoot out of the ground, grabbing for his ankles. He leaps up, kicking off one tree trunk to grab another one's branches. He swings off, lands and rolls. Now all the trees are moving to block him, their dark shapes towering over him in the flashes of LIGHTNING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he ducks under branches, the chain holding the Key to the City gets caught. He's almost strangled, but the chain finally breaks. The silver key disappears into the mud. Scrambling forward, he looks for a way out. But the trees have encircled him, their spiky crowns bending down to crush him. He SCREAMS up at the night, until his breath is gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a sudden calm...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another lightning FLASH, and suddenly the trees are back where they've always been. Edward is lying shoeless and torn in a muddy puddle, staring up at the rain. And LAUGHING.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jenny thinks you're quite a catch. We all do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not hearing) What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said you're quite a catch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to leave. Tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This town is everything a man could ask for. And if I were to end up here, I'd consider myself lucky. But the fact is, I'm not ready to end up anywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one's ever left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How are you gonna make it without your shoes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suspect it will hurt a lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling after him) You won't find a better place!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't expect to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Promise me you'll come back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I promise. Someday. When I'm really supposed to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) As difficult as it was to reach Spectre, I was fated to get there eventually. After all, no man can avoid reaching the end of his life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And then I realized, this wasn't the end of my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (aloud) This isn't how I die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: His bare foot steps onto asphalt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward turns to see
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Friend!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to his right, coming down the larger, paved road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward looks down at his muddy, bloody feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With that, the men start walking down the larger road.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What happened to your shoes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They got ahead of me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward and Will sit at opposite ends of the table, with Sandra and Josephine in the middle. Although Edward has a small plate of food in front of him, he hasn't touched it. He's exhausted from the trip downstairs, but determined to maintain the family dinner ritual. The other three eat awkwardly, each CLINK and SCRAPE of a knife or fork resonating. Will finally breaks the silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat. As Will scoops out another serving of potatoes, Edward suddenly speaks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All three stop to listen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taking the bait...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know if you've seen it, but Josephine has some photos in the most recent Newsweek.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really! That's wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I spent a week in Morocco for the story. It was incredible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll have to pick up a copy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know if you're aware of this, Josephine, but African parrots, in their native home of the Congo -- they speak only French.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amused) Really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're lucky to get four words out of them in English. But if you were to walk through the jungle, you'd hear them speaking the most elaborate French. Those parrots talk about everything: politics, movies, fashion -- everything but religion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not religion, Dad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's rude to talk about religion. You never know who you're going to offend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Josephine actually went to the Congo last year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, so you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Will shakes a shopping cart free from the pile-up while his mother checks her list.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sandra starts to bag string beans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's more amused than annoyed, but Will is entering dangerous territory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She moves on to the carrots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a look, Sandra acknowledges the stakes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mom, would you say you understand Dad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What I mean is, do you really know what's going on in his head? SANDRA Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How is that possible? I mean, you try to ask him a question and suddenly it's another one of his stories. (decidedly) You can't honestly say you know him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Will, I do. And don't presume things you don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you say you understand Josephine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. But that's a different...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No it's not. It's exactly the same. Your father and I met, we dated, and we married -- we chose each other -- because we understood each other on some fundamental level. Just the same as you two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Josephine and I have a lot in common.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, you both think William Bloom is a very smart man. (beat) The problem is, you only see me as your mother, and not as someone's wife. And I've been his wife longer than I've been your mother. You can't discount that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: True. But I've known him my whole life, and I don't feel like I know him at all. Or ever will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know it's not easy. Just remember, he didn't choose to be your father and you didn't choose to be his son. You just ended up together. You could pick numbers out of a dark bag and it'd be just the same. If you ask me, it's a wonder parents and children can stand each other at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I understand you, Mom. I always have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, clearly you don't. But I'm not the mystery you're trying to solve right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Reaching the CASHIER, Sandra hands over her coupons. Will is approaching with a Newsweek magazine. Two checkstands over, an ATTRACTIVE BLONDE WOMAN in her 50's is getting her change. Though she's Sandra's generation, she carries herself like a much younger woman, with blue jeans and sneakers. She accidentally makes eye contact with Will as he passes. We HOLD ON the woman, who tracks Will as he reaches Sandra. It's hard to read her reaction: does she recognize him, or just find him attractive? Will notices the gaze. The woman turns away. Will racks his brain -- does he know this woman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sandra looks. After a beat, the Blonde Woman turns again, semi-casually. Noticing that both Will and Sandra are looking, she smiles a little before taking her cart to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Cashier turns to look. He can only get a profile as the woman leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Before I forget, your father has papers in the basement I'd like you to go through. I wouldn't know what's important.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (distracted) Mom, do you know who that is? Blonde hair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (no idea) Was she one of your teachers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. But it's weird. She seemed to recognize me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the cashier) Do you know who that is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never seen her before. Pretty, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A portable fan quietly WHIRRS in the corner. Turned low, the RADIO on the nightstand is playing a call-in AM sports show, just a wash of background chatter. Edward lies asleep on his back. At the window, Josephine quietly lowers the shade. She reaches over Edward to switch off the radio. He stirs from the silence -- he wasn't fully asleep -- and sees Josephine stretched over him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tries to recollect, but it's already gone. Josephine motions, is it okay for her to sit on the bed? He nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sits up a bit in bed, his strength returning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long beat. Then, deadpan...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods, a bit more of a laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Edward continues, she can't help but laugh harder, especially as the metaphors get more vulgar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's starting to cry from laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With that, he stops. She regains her composure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rolls his eyes, why not. Josephine leaves, heading down the hall to get her camera. We STAY WITH Edward in bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward grimaces, a flash of pain. Around others, he's hiding how much it hurts, but alone we can see how bad it is. He controls his breathing, trying to push through it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She returns with her camera. Edward smiles, doing a good job masking the pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A devilish smile. Pushing past Edward, we settle on the whirling fan.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (playfully lecherous) Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi. How are you feeling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was dreaming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What were you dreaming about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't usually remember unless they're especially portentous. You know what that word means, portentous?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Means when you dream about something that's going to happen. (beat, gathering) Like one night, I had a dream where this crow came and told me, "Your Aunt is going to die." I was so scared I woke up my parents. They told me it was just a dream, to go back to bed. But the next morning, my Aunt Stacy was dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's terrible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Terrible for her, but think about me, young boy with that kind of power. Wasn't three weeks later that the crow came back to me in a dream and said, "Your Grampa is going to die." Well, I ran right back to my parents. My father said, no, Gramps is fine, but I could see there was trepidation. And true enough, that next morning my Grampa was dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For the next couple weeks, I didn't have another dream. Until one night the crow came back and said, "Your Daddy is going to die." (beat) Well, I didn't know what to do. But finally I told my father. And he said not to worry, but I could tell he was rattled. That next day, he wasn't himself, always looking around, waiting for something to drop on his head. Because the crow didn't tell how it was going to happen, just those words: your Daddy is going to die. Well, he went into town early and was gone for a long time. And when he finally came back, he looked terrible, like he was waiting for the axe to fall all day. He said to my mother, "Good God. I just had the worst day of my life." (beat) "You think you've had a bad day," she said. "This morning the milkman dropped dead on the porch!" Josephine smiles, a half-laugh, which gets him smiling too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because see, my mother was banging the milkman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was slipping her a little extra cream.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was filling her basket. He was making deliveries around back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was buttering her rolls. Pumping her churn. Splashing milk in her box.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They were squeezing the cheese. Clanking the bottles. Licking the popsicle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cracking the eggs and making an omelet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Spooning the sherbet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) Can I take your picture?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't need a picture. Just look up handsome in the dictionary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) I have photos from the wedding to show you. There's a great one of you and my father. I had an extra print made.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to see pictures of your wedding. I've never seen any.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's because we didn't have a wedding. Your mother-in-law was never supposed to marry me. She was engaged to somebody else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (loading film) I never knew.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will never told you that? (she shakes her head) Probably just as well. He would have told it all wrong anyway. All the facts and none of the flavor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, so this is a tall tale?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's not a short one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: held by a LITTLE BOY. He's slumped over his FATHER's shoulder, being carried towards a big-top tent. We are...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...where the second-rate carnival is parked for the moment in an Alabama field. To the left, we spot Edward, 20-ish, halfway through a bag of peanuts. He's still carrying the backpack we saw earlier, and scratched up from his trip through Spectre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joining the crowd, he heads into the big-top.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I had just left Ashton, and was on my way to discover my destiny. Not knowing what that would be exactly, I explored every opportunity that presented itself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A troupe of STILT-WALKING FIREBREATHERS finishes their act to tremendous APPLAUSE. As the performers clear away, the circus' owner-and-ringmaster AMOS CALLOWAY (50) approaches the stands. He may only be four feet tall, but Amos has a titanic presence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From behind Amos, CARNIES start rolling a massive ball towards the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amos comes up to a MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN in the first row, a quieter moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The carnies back away from the ball as a deep DRUM ROLL begins. A moment, then the ball starts to bulge from inside. A foot suddenly bursts out from within. GASPS from the crowd. That foot is massive. In the stands, Edward looks closer. Intrigued. As the drum beat intensifies, a second foot breaks out. Followed by hands. Shoulders. Finally, the head. This is COLOSSUS. From a very LOW ANGLE, we look up to see just how massive he is. He seems to fill the Heavens. With his shaved head and giant club, he seems more ogre than man. In the bandstands, a YOUNG BOY's jaw drops in awe. Colossus walks down the row, letting the crowd get a better look at him. Some reach out to touch him, disbelieving. A tight spotlight follows him, revealing faces in the crowd. Colossus passes Edward, who seems unimpressed. He leans with the spotlight, WHISTLING to get the big man's attention. He points to the edge of the stands, where his friend is sitting on the dirt -- KARL THE GIANT stands up, so big the spotlight has to widen just to hold him. He's a good foot taller than Colossus. There's a GASP from the crowd, along with nervous anticipation -- what will happen next?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ladies and Gentlemen, you may think you've seen the unusual. You may think you've seen the bizarre. But I've travelled to the five corners of the world, and let me tell you, I've never seen anything like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I found this man, he was picking oranges in Florida. His fellow workers called him El Penumbra -- The Shadow -- because when you were working beside him, he blocked out the daylight. He could take a whole tree in his hands and shake off the fruit. I had to pay his crew boss $10,000 just so I could take him with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not to alarm you, Ma'am. But if this man wanted to, he could crush your head between his toes. (she trembles) But he won't. (a long beat) He's not going to hurt her, folks, because he's our own Gentle Giant. Ladies and Gentlemen, I give you Colossus!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ON Amos, stunned, megaphone dangling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON Colossus, realizing the gig is up. With a resigned shrug, he rests his club on his shoulder and walks away into the shadows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the stands empty, Edward and Karl talk to Amos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CONTINUOUS As Amos pulls Karl aside to give him the hard sell, Edward notices a BEAUTIFUL YOUNG WOMAN (16) leaving with her family. She's wearing a blue dress and hat. For no good reason, she looks back at Edward. The two make eye contact. And as they do, all motion FREEZES. A fiery baton remains mid-twirl, flames locked in place. A spilled box of popcorn hangs in mid-air, each kernel like a snowflake. Even the elephant is mid-poop. Only Edward is free to move, winding his way between the frozen bodies, ducking underneath arms to get closer and closer to this woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, everything RUSHES. The crowd becomes a blur, and the young woman is lost in its wake. Now it's Edward who's frozen, helpless in time.

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) They say when you meet the love of your life, time stops. And that's true. What they don't tell you, is that once time starts again, it moves extra fast to catch up.

He dodges four SHOTS that knock down the birds around him. He catches his breath, lucky. Then a half-blind OLD WOMAN pulls her trigger, hitting him in the shoulder.

direction.raw_text: Under a full moon, Edward walks up to the battered camper, and is about to knock when he notices it's rocking. A lot. Not just that, there's MOANING coming from inside. But Edward KNOCKS anyway.

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, the rocking and moaning stop. A beat, then the door handle begins to RATTLE. It seems to be stuck. Edward turns the knob. Suddenly, the door BURSTS OPEN. Edward is knocked down by a massive black dog, biggest you've ever seen. It has green glowing eyes and a lick of fire for a tongue. Edward wrestles with the beast, its mouth snapping at his throat. Blocking with an arm, Edward tries to push himself free, but the creature's hands -- it has hands instead of paws -- hold on tight. Entwined, they roll across the dirt. The other nearby CARNIES scatter for cover. Mr. Soggybottom pulls a revolver out of his clown suit. Loads a silver bullet. Edward finally succeeds in throwing the beast off. He rolls to his feet. The hell hound squares back on its haunches, GROWLING, ready for another leap. Mr. Soggybottom sheds a clown tear, aiming the revolver at the dog. At the last moment...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward moves just as Mr. Soggybottom FIRES. The bullet catches Edward in the shoulder, knocking him down. The carnies GASP. Licking its chops, the dog approaches the helpless Edward, who feels the ground around him, looking for some kind of weapon. He finds only a small stick. He waves it at the dog, ready to strike it. Like magic, the dog's whole demeanor changes. It bounces excitedly, ready to play fetch. Seeing an opportunity, Edward throws the stick as far as he can. The dog bounds after it,
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Calloway! It's Edward Bloom. I need to talk to you.

dialogue.raw_text: No, wait!

dialogue.raw_text: It was that night I discovered that most things you consider evil or wicked are simply lonely, and lacking in the social niceties.

direction.raw_text: We DESCEND ON the main quad, to find Edward Bloom dunking his head in the fountain. He changes out of his grubby shirt into a new one, just out of the package. It's the mid-1960's, but by the conservative dress of the passing STUDENTS, it could be any era.

Through the crack we can see the edge of a YOUNG WOMAN, talking in hushed tones with another girl we can't see. Finally, a decision is reached. The door opens to reveal the woman of Edward's dreams, Sandra Kay Templeton. She's effortlessly beautiful, pure and simple as sunlight. He can't believe he's finally reached her. He half-laughs, nervous. That makes her laugh, not sure what's going on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You don't know me, but my name is Edward Bloom and I am in love with you. I've spent the last three years working to find out who you are. I've been shot and stabbed and trampled a few times, had my ribs broken twice, but it's all worth it to see you here, now, and to finally get to talk to you. Because I am destined to marry you. I knew that from the first moment I saw you at the circus. And I know it now more than ever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

He twists and struggles, trying to free himself. Looking down, he can see the white parachutes disappearing into the darkness. They're already long gone. Digging a knife out of his pocket, Edward gets to work cutting through the cable. It finally POPS. Edward jumps from the plane.

The lights go out as a DRUM ROLL begins. It's just enough cover for Edward to remain unseen. He lands with a CLANG on the lighting catwalk above the stage. He barely grabs on, disconnecting his chute just as the curtain goes up. Edward looks out at the sea of excited soldiers. Every one of them would kill him. He's the legless cricket left on the anthill.

dialogue.raw_text: You have to understand. When I was growing up, he was gone more than he was here. And I started thinking -- maybe he has a second life somewhere else. With another house, another family. He leaves us, he goes to them. Or maybe there is no family. Maybe he never wanted a family. But whatever it is, maybe he likes that second life better. And the reason he tells all those stories is because he can't stand this boring place.

dialogue.raw_text: You tell lies, Dad. You tell amusing lies. Stories are what you tell a five-year old at bedtime. They're not elaborate mythologies you maintain when your son is ten and fifteen and twenty and thirty. And the thing is, I believed you. I believed your stories so much longer than I should have. And then when I realized that everything you said was impossible -- everything! -- I felt like such a fool to have trusted you. You were like Santa Claus and the Easter Bunny combined. direction.raw_text: With a skimmer pole, Will cleans the leaves and debris out of the pool, but it's a fool's errand. The pool has long since gone native, a shiny slick of algae on the surface, slime covering the cemented rocks. Suddenly, an underwater shape RIPPLES against the water's surface. Will is so startled that he drops the pole, which disappears into the murky water. A beat. He looks around, relieved that no one saw that. He casually walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doors open to reveal Sandra, Will and Josephine, staring into the mouth of oblivion. The storeroom is a museum of hasty decisions and half-finished projects: partially built outboard motors, dead bonsai trees, Frankensteinian lawnmowers. We also find boxes of products Edward used to sell. Clearing a path, Sandra leads Will to a roll-top desk, its ribs covered in dust. Two beaten metal file cabinets sit beside it.
