direction.raw_text: Will is headed upstairs when his mother comes around the corner with an armful of laundry, including her wet dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She passes him. He turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will quickly debates whether or not to ask her...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will nods, just curious. He continues heading up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is he awake?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He just fell asleep. Josephine's with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you and Dad have any other property?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinking) I suppose your grandmother's house when she passed on. But we sold that right away. Your cousin Shirley bought it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you never bought any land.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Heavens no. We had a hard enough time keeping the mortgage on this place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Will changes his shirt. Takes his keys off the nightstand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will's rental car drives past a sign reading, "Ashton, 10 miles."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will checks the address on one of his father's files.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will talks to the ATTENDANT, who points him in a direction, then gestures a series of left, right, left, rights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will drives down a road that seems somewhat familiar. And then we realize why: a roadsign reads "Welcome to Spectre!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sitting at the edge of a swamp, the little two-story feels lonely, set deep in its lot. Dapples of light break through the trees, a light breeze swaying the branches. As Will walks from the car, the WHIRR of cicadas grows. He checks the number: 33. This is the house. It is surrounded by a white square-picket fence, identical to his mother's. Will notices this. Reaching the porch, we hear a PIANO playing inside. Badly. Re-checking the number on a form he's carrying, Will KNOCKS. The piano stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The piano starts again. FOOTSTEPS. The door opens to reveal a blonde woman in her 50's -- the woman from the grocery store. Her name is Jenny Hill. She and Will are startled to see each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Confused, Will checks the name on the form.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The PIANO STUDENT, a black boy of eight, has stopped. He's watching the conversation at the door. Speaking of awkward...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands him five dollars out of her pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have to tell him twice. He's out the door in a flash.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Go back to the start. Right hand only.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wasn't expecting you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you Jenny Hill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am. And you're Will. I've seen your picture, that's how I recognize you. I almost said something at the store, but it would have been awkward. (a beat) Like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the student) Listen, Kenny. Why don't we skip the lesson today? We can go again next week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do I have to give it back to my Mom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't tell her if you won't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: While Will sips his iced tea, Jenny flips through a form she never expected to see again. She hands it back to Will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat. Not flinching...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She moves, trying to get out of the corner he's boxed her into. Once she's finally free...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long beat. Jenny is taken back by the suddenness of it. She's a tangle of conflicting emotions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fair enough. Jenny takes a seat across from him at the table.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How did you know my father?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This was on his sales route, so he was through here all the time. Everyone in town knew him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Were you and my father having an affair?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taken aback) Wow. Wow, you just said it. I was expecting to dance around this for another half hour.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've seen him with women. He flirts. He always has. On some level, I presumed he was cheating on my mother. I just never had proof.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I ask you a question? Why did you come here today? If you found this deed, why didn't you just ask Eddie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because he's dying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I don't know how much you want to know about any of this. You have one image of your father and it would be wrong for me to go and change it. Especially this late in the game.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father talked about a lot of things he never did, and I'm sure he did a lot of things he never talked about. I'm just trying to reconcile the two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The first thing you have to understand, is that your father never meant to end up here. And yet he did, twice. The first time, he was early. The second time, he was late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's late, and Edward is pensive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first raindrops hit the windshield. Edward turns on the wipers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Those days, your father was working for himself. If there was one thing you could say about Edward Bloom, it's that he was a social person, and people took a liking to him. One night he was returning from three weeks on the road, when he hit a thunderstorm unlike any in his life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - [THE STORM] Suddenly, a deluge descends. It's not even rain anymore -- there's no space between the drops. It's like being caught in a waterfall. It's that loud. No choice, Edward stops the car. Puts on the handbrake. Just as suddenly, the sound changes -- no longer pounding, but softly SPLASHING. The world is close and echoing, because -- EXT. EDWARD'S CAR - NIGHT -- the car is underwater. The tires are still on the road, but where there used to be air is water. Three catfish swim in front of his headlights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Realizing his plight, Edward tries to remain calm. Water is trickling in through the crack between the window and the door, but very slowly. For now, he's fine. That's when he sees her -- The Girl in the River. She's swimming outside the car. While we never see her face exactly, she remains just as beautiful, just as mysterious, as the first time we saw her. She puts her hand to the windshield. He puts his up to meet hers. And smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's morning, and the sun shines brightly. Birds CHIRP. Trees drip and the grass shines, still wet from last night's rain. Edward gathers the clothes that have spilled out of his suitcase, which broke open when he dropped it from
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: which balances precariously ten feet up in an elm tree. As Edward gathers his last pair of socks, he notices a shiny piece of metal sticking out of the dirt. He pulls it out, rubs it off. It's a key. It's the Key to the City he lost years ago.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Fate has a way of circling back on a man, and taking him by surprise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carrying his busted suitcase, a tired Edward walks toward a one-street town in the distance. We pass a rusty sign... "Welcome to Spectre."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amazed and disbelieving, Edward walks down the center of the road, no cars coming from either direction. He looks up to find his faded shoes still dangling from the power line, along with the rest of the town's.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) A man sees things differently at different times in his life. This town didn't seem the same now that he was older.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We look around the town, on and off Main Street. There are "FOR SALE" signs in many of the windows
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) A new road had brought the outside world to Spectre, and with it, banks, liens and debt. Almost everywhere you looked, people were bankrupt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We slowly MOVE THROUGH a foreclosure auction to find Edward watching. Two very corporate MEN IN SUITS, stick out among the bidders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward raises his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone turns to look at this new bidder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Two different corporations were looking at buying the town, if they could get the price low enough. One wanted to open a chicken processing plant. The other, a municipal dump. Either way, Spectre would be destroyed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fifty-thousand!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And so Edward Bloom decided to buy the town, in order to save it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward pitches his plan to Norther.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) He was never a wealthy man, but he had made other men rich, and now he asked for their favors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Expressive and passionate as always, Edward talks to Ping, Jing and Amos Calloway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Edward takes notes...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Most of them had never seen Spectre -- they only had Edward's words to describe it. That's all they needed. He sold them on the dream.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can structure it as a historical trust. But you'll need every contiguous piece of property. It's all or nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) So first he bought the farms. Then he bought the houses. Then he bought the stores.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Finishing up with AL, Edward shakes hands.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Whatever he bought, the people were not asked to leave or pay rent or anything. They were just asked to keep doing as they were doing. In that way, he could make sure the town would never die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward climbs out of his car, the road having literally stopped. The sun is shining, but it can barely penetrate the trees' thick canopy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the distance, he sees a shack, so old it's nearly fallen. He walks toward it, the marshy ground SQUISHING up around his feet, soaking the hems of his trousers. We hear a PIANO playing from inside the shack. Edward KNOCKS on the half-hung door, which swings open by itself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Within six months, his trust had purchased the entire town. With one exception.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The inside is nicer than you'd think, a real home. A fire burns in the stove, and curtains hang in the windows. With her back turned to him, Jenny Hill plays the piano. Edward doesn't recognize her as the little girl who used to have a crush on him. Without turning, she says...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She keeps PLAYING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jenny stops playing, her piece not quite finished. She turns to face him. Edward still doesn't recognize her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Strange to hear it put that way, but -- EDWARD In so many words, yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her, puzzled and surprised. No one has really asked before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She finally turns to face him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You must be Edward Bloom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one would come out here unless they had business. And no one would have business with me except for you. You're buying the town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Apparently I've overlooked this one piece of it, and I'd like to remedy that. You see, in order for the town to be preserved, the trust must own it in its entirety.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So I've heard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll offer you more than it's worth. And you know you won't have to move. Nothing will change except the name on the deed, you have my word.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now let me get this straight. You'll buy the swamp from me, but I'll stay in it. You'll own the house, but it'll still be mine. I'll be here, and you'll come and go as you please to one place or another. Do I have that right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I don't think so Mr. Bloom. If nothing is going to change, I'd just as soon it not change in the way it hasn't been changing all this time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not like you're going to lose anything. You can ask anyone in town. I've been nothing if not generous. I want the best for everyone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Bloom, why are you buying this land? Some sort of midlife crisis? Instead of buying a convertible, you buy a town?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Helping people makes me happy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not convinced you should be happy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. Have I offended you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you did exactly what you promised. You came back. I was just expecting you sooner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Young Jenny Hill watches barefoot Edward leave Spectre for the first time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally realizing who this woman is...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before he can say anything more...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bit bewildered, Edward tips his hat to her as he leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're Beamen's daughter. Your last name is different. (realizing) You married.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was 18. He was 28. Turns out that was a big difference.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't be selling you this house, Mr. Bloom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see. I thank you for your time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SWAMP SHACK - DAY Edward pulls the door shut behind him as he leaves, but it breaks off in his hands. It's not the clean exit he was hoping for. Inside Jenny looks out, surprised and annoyed. Edward tries to lift the door back on the hinges, but they SNAP off. The door frame buckles and the whole shack CREAKS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tries to lean the door against the frame, but it keeps slipping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans the door a different way. It holds for a beat then falls in, SMASHING a small table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's dead serious. Weighing the scales of chivalry, he finally backs away. Turns and heads back towards his car. We STAY ON Jenny, watching him go. She's furious, but there's something more in her feelings for him. Something softer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's okay, just leave it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can get it. I can just...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lord, I'm sorry I...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please. Go. Just go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Most men in that situation would accept their failure and move on. But Edward was not like most men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: With Karl the Giant's help, Edward unloads a brand new door from a pickup truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: While Jenny watches, half-annoyed, half-amused, Edward tries to set the door square. Karl pushes against the side of the house until it fits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holding nails between his lips, Edward puts in new windows himself. Jenny is making soup, laughing at the story he's telling.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) As the months passed, he found more and more things to fix, until the shack no longer resembled itself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward and Karl cut down a tree, letting in a flood of light. Through the golden pollen hanging in the air, we RISE UP to see the shack is now
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: we saw before. It's tiny and white, with black shutters and a steep roof. A white picket fence. In every detail it is impossibly charming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward is screwing a hat rack into the wall in the foyer. Jenny leans against the doorframe listening to his story. And watching him with deepest affection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finished with his work, he takes his hat off the chair and hangs it on the rack. Perfect. A beat. A look between them. With that last job done, there's no reason for him to be staying any longer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes his hat off the rack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat. Does she really mean it? She comes closer. Edward holds his ground. She takes his hand, lifting his hat up to the peg. She's very close -- just a half-inch from kissing him when -- -- Edward gently holds her back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She freezes, stunned and humiliated. She pulls away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With that, he begins to leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She finds a pen and hastily signs the deed to the house. Hands it to him. With a look, he thanks her. Then goes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, the best part was creating new material. By the time the twins and I got to Havana, we had a whole new routine worked out for them, with just a ukulele and a harmonica.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose I should...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can leave it there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't. Don't be embarrassed. I should never have let you think that... (beat) I am in love with my wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And from the moment I saw her until the moment I die, she's the only one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lucky girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, Jenny. I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait! Edward!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward takes a final look at this perfect little town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He climbs in his car and starts the engine.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) One day, Edward Bloom left, and never returned to the town he'd saved.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As we watch, the swamp begins to overtake the house, swallowing it in a tangle of vines and mossy branches. Shoots burst up through the planks in the porch. Snakes slither through the marsh. Day becomes night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We REVERSE to find FOUR KIDS looking in through the rusty iron gate with flashlights. A beat, then they run away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) As for the girl, the common belief was that she'd become a witch, and crazy at that. She became something of a legend herself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And the story ended where it began.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Will and Jenny are still sitting at her table, a pitcher of iced tea between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will smiles to hear it called that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her composure is starting to break.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long beat, both staring at their iced tea. Jenny is working herself into more of a state by not talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's fighting tears, not the first ones she's shed over this.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Logically, you couldn't be the Witch, because she was old back when he was young.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it's logical if you think like your father. See, to him, there's only two women: your mother and everyone else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't become crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, therapy. And one day I realized I was in love with a man who could never love me back. I was living in a fairy tale.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: People aren't like they are in stories. They hurt each other without meaning to. They are kind and unbelievably cruel at the same moment. Like me, now. I'm not sure I should have told you any of this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I wanted to know. I'm glad I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wanted to meet you for the longest time. I did. (a smile) I envied you so much. The way Eddie would talk about you when you were at Missouri, that award you won. Congratulations, incidentally. And when you got the job at the A.P., everything, he was so proud of you. I mean, that's the thing. Every moment he loved you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And as brightly as the sun would shine when he was with me, every time he left it disappeared. I wanted to be as important to him as you were, and I was never going to be. I was make-believe and his other life, you, were real.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ON Will, sorting through his swirling thoughts.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You knew that, didn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Will skips through the stations on the radio, but ultimately turns it off. He's trying to think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will walks up the front steps. There's a subtle change to his expression, a dark cloud lifted. He unlocks the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's half-dark and quiet in the house, no talking, no TV. Will sets his keys on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will looks in. Empty.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calling out) Hello? Mom? Dad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We follow Will, looking into his and Josephine's room. He aims for the guest room at the end of the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looking over his shoulder, we see his father's bed is empty. The sheets are in a tangle on the floor. A beat, then Will half-runs back down the hall. Back down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Headed out, Will grabs his keys off the table. We LOOK RIGHT, where the "MESSAGE" light blinks on the answering machine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hospital is so new, it's not even finished -- thick plastic hangs from exposed framing. There's no one at the information desk, so Will forges ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will reads a directory board, trying to decide the best place to start. Then, behind him -- JOSEPHINE (O.S.) Will! He turns to see his wife at a payphone. She hangs up. She was calling him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat. How can she answer? He half-smiles, realizing the idiocy of his question. Of course his father's not going to be okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She cuts him off -- JOSEPHINE No. He won't. I'm sorry. And like that, it's done. We HOLD ON Will, reeling from the news.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your father had a stroke. He's upstairs with your mom and Dr. Bennett.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he going to be okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What I mean is, will he get back to the way he was when...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward sleeps peacefully, just an oxygen tube under his nose. There are no beeping monitors, no blinking lights. It's mercifully quiet. Sandra squeezes Will's hand tightly. She's holding herself together, but it's been a tough day. Dr. Bennett has just gone through the details for the third time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A nod, then Will holds the door for Dr. Bennett and Josephine as they leave. Sandra is alone in the room with her husband. She neatens his hair. Holds his hand. As she kisses his fingers, she tweaks her chin with them -- his signature move.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't suppose one of us could stay with him. In case he... (beat) In case he wakes up, one of us should be there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll stay. Why don't you go home with Josephine and I'll stay tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Dr. Bennett) That's okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT It's fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Will) You'll call if...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will. I'll call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mom, do you want some time with Dad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sandra waits outside the women's restroom. Her face is a study in strained composure -- acknowledging the inevitable but refusing to surrender to it. Josephine emerges.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two women start to walk, no hurry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sandra has accidentally evoked a storm of emotion. She struggles to keep it in check. Almost a whisper...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a few breaths, Sandra tries to hold on. Hold back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat, then Sandra finally melts. Josephine holds her. The two women stand together in the hallway, letting the moment be.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. It seems every hour I have to...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. It was the same when I was carrying Will. Like clockwork.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you like it, being pregnant?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I loved it. It sounds peculiar, but I loved every minute of it. I did. Eddie was travelling a lot, so he was gone, but I felt like I always had a piece of him with me. A little part of his soul inside me. I could feel it. It was alive and kicking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I really miss that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't stop. Don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Will sits in a chair beside the bed, working through the crossword puzzle. A KNOCK as Dr. Bennett enters with his overcoat and bag, ready to leave for the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Bennett smiles as he checks Edward's chart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tables turned, Will searches for an answer. He doesn't have one. Dr. Bennett hangs the chart back on the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long silence, just the sounds of the hospital, doctors being paged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will half-smiles. Patting Will's shoulder, Dr. Bennett leaves. We STAY ON Will and his father for a long time, then Will takes his pen and starts making a list.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT Glad to see you're not trying to have a heartfelt talk. It's one of my greatest annoyances, when people talk to those who can't hear them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father and I have an advantage. We never talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long have you known my father?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT Thirty years. Maybe more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How would you describe him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT (re: chart) Five-eleven. One-eighty. Regulated hypertension. (beat) How would his son describe him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT Did your father ever tell you about the day you were born?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A thousand times. He caught an uncatchable fish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT Not that one. The real story. Did he ever tell you that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly interested) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT Your mother came in about three in the afternoon. Her neighbor drove her, on account of your father was on business in Wichita. You were born a week early, but there were no complications. It was a perfect delivery. Now, your father was sorry to miss it, but it wasn't the custom for the men to be in the room for deliveries then, so I can't see as it would have been much different had he been there. And that's the real story of how you were born.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT Not very exciting, is it? And I suppose if I had to choose between the true version and an elaborate one involving a fish and a wedding ring, I might choose the fancy version. But that's just me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Will flips to a new page. The list keeps getting longer. He smiles, remembering something. On his fourth page, he looks up at his motionless father. A beat, then we slowly
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's very early morning, and the first blue light of day is glowing through the vertical blinds. Still in his chair, Will wakes up a bit at a time. The notepad is on his lap, the pen in his hand. He cracks his neck, crooked from sleeping on it wrong. What woke him up? He looks to his right. Holds his gaze for a breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His father is awake, silently GASPING for breath. His eyes are open, scared and confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward shakes his head unambiguously. Will already has his finger on the orange "nurse call" button, but doesn't push it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward nods. Will pours a glass from the pitcher on the nightstand. He holds it to his father's lips, but Edward won't drink. He pushes it away. He wanted something else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It takes Edward all his strength to put together each thought. It's like he's only half-there, fighting to hang on to this world.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dad! Do you want me to get a nurse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What can I do? Can I help? Can I get you something? Water?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering) The river.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The river?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me how it happens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How what happens?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How I go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: realizing...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward nods. Yes, that's what he was trying to say. A long beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will pushes his fingers under his father's heavy hand, and holds it. There's nothing else to do. Edward looks around, confused and increasingly scared. He sees the end approaching, but doesn't know exactly what's coming. Without the story, he's lost. Fighting the urge to panic -- WILL I can try, Dad. If you help. Just tell me how it starts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will looks around the room, increasingly desperate. He looks to the nurse call button. He really wants to press it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You mean what you saw in The Eye?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know that story, Dad. You never told me that one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: waiting for Will to begin.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. It's morning, and you and I are in the hospital. I'd fallen asleep in the chair. I wake up and I see you, and...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: [STORY VERSION]
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's dawn, and the first golden glow is shining through the vertical blinds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We LOOK OVER to find a nimble Edward sitting up in bed, combing his hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Edward throws back the covers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will heads for the bathroom. Sure enough, the wheelchair is there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (louder and concerned) Dad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's get out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Somehow, you're better. Different. You're getting ready to go. And I say...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dad, you're in no condition to...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a fold-up wheelchair in the bathroom. Wrap a blanket around me. As soon as we get off this floor, we'll be in the clear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hurry! We don't have much time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: With the blanket draped over his head like a ghost, Edward points for his son to steer the wheelchair thataway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They pass a HEAVYSET NURSE, who turns to look. Rounding a corner, they nearly crash into Dr. Bennett.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before he can answer, Will spots Edward rolling the chair himself, pumping both arms. Will dashes to catch up with him. The Heavyset Nurse leans out of Edward's hospital room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Faster!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BENNETT Will! I... What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Security! Stop them!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: At the elevators, Sandra and Josephine step out to find Will and Edward barreling straight at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seeing SECURITY GUARDS heading their way, a quick-thinking Sandra shoves a nearby cart into them, bowling them down.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No time to explain! Follow us!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Will brakes hard, sliding with both feet. The chair nearly crashes into the back wall as the doors close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will races Edward down the row, finally reaching the Chevrolet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will lifts his father out of the chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will sets him in the passenger seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scrambling in back, Will finds a liter of Arrowhead. Hands it off. Edward unscrews the cap, but instead of drinking it, he douses himself. Soaks the blanket. Will pops the trunk. Starts to fold up the wheelchair.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I pick you up and you hardly weigh anything. I can't explain it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Water. I need water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave it! We won't need it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as the car peals out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: [REALITY]
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will, trying to hold back tears as he talks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And we have to take Glenville to avoid all the church traffic, because those damn church people drive too slow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edward, enjoying that detail. He's focused completely on Will's story.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I ask...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . - DAY [STORY VERSION] The Chevy slaloms through the Sunday-morning traffic.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Where are we headed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) You say...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The River! Will stops short, the traffic backed up. He HONKS, trying to get around the jam. But it's no use. Then, up ahead, the cars start moving, shoved aside by massive hands. It's Karl the Giant, clearing a path by brute force. Edward leans out the window and waves. Karl waves back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The same stretch of the river where it all began. A CROWD of more than 100 waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amos Calloway is here with the circus folk, including Mr. Soggybottom. We also find Edward's Mother and Father, the Mayor, and many others from along the way. No one has aged a day since we saw them last. While Ping scans the horizon, Jing nuzzles with her boyfriend, Norther Winslow. It's Ping who first spots the Chevrolet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd CHEERS. The Ashton marching band PLAYS. Jenny Hill smiles. So does the Old Woman. We PUSH IN on the Old Woman's glass eye, where we see...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) As we get closer to the river, we see everybody's already there. And I mean everybody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: reflected. This is what he saw.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amazed, Will turns to his father.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's unbelievable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Story of my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Will gets out of the Chevrolet, overwhelmed by the crowd. Behind him, Sandra, Josephine and Dr. Bennett pull up. Karl comes just after that. Crossing to the passenger side, Will lifts his father out. Strangely, he's gotten even lighter. Will carries him easily. Edward pulls off his shoes, tying the laces together. He hands them to Josephine. She throws them up at the powerline. They loop over. APPLAUSE and CHEERS. The crowd parts to let Will and Edward get to the river. As he passes, Edward shakes some hands, pats some people on the cheek, and gives others a good poke in the ribs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will walks into the river, up to his knees. He turns back so his father can face the crowd. Edward waves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But one face is missing from the crowd -- Sandra. Will turns to see she's already standing in the river beside them. The reflection of the light off the water gives Sandra an unearthly glow. She's more tranquil and more beautiful than we've ever seen her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses him. He tweaks her chin. The crowd HOLLERS in approval, but their moment remains strangely private. Only Will is there to witness. As the kiss ends, Edward tries to pull off his wedding ring. But it's stuck. Finally, he sucks on it, pulling it free with his teeth. A look to Will, a smile with a glint of gold. Will takes the ring out of his mouth. Edward suddenly drops out of Will's arms with a SPLASH. For he's no longer a man, but rather
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And the strange thing is, there's not a sad face to be found. Everyone's just so glad to see you, and send you off right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye everybody! Farewell! Adieu!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye Edward! / See ya! / We'll miss you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My girl in the river.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: swimming at his feet. We watch as the catfish circles, then heads for deeper water, disappearing. Will and his mother stand knee-deep in the water, watching Edward Bloom swim away into the sunlight. Josephine is back on the shore, along with the entire crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to a climax, then... Down the river, a GIANT FISH suddenly jumps out of the water, cutting a beautiful arc across the sunset. It then dives back under with a SPLASH.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will has tears hanging in the corners of his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward smiles, proud of both of them. His eyes are so pale and so open, we can almost see his soul. In every atom of his body, in every thought, Edward Bloom is entirely happy. And this is how he goes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You become what you always were. A very big fish. (he smiles) And that's the way it happens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a whisper) Yes. Exactly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Will shuts the door to his father's room behind him. The walk to the payphones seems to take a lifetime. He finds a quarter, starts to dial. He has to squint to see through the water in his eyes. It's ringing. And ringing. The other end answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all he can get out before the dam breaks inside him. He presses closer to the phone, trying to shield himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (voice cracking) Hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: begins that will carry us through the next passage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will waits at reception as Sandra and Josephine come off the elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Josephine opens the curtains, letting white sunlight in. She strips the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will and his mother pick out one of Edward's ties, for Will to wear at the funeral. Will tries to button the cuffs on the shirt he borrowed, but they're the kind that need links. He goes through the top drawer of the dresser, trying to find a matching pair. Further down, he finds a ribbon tied to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He smiles, disbelieving. It's a real thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will helps his mother out of a black sedan. She's well- composed, not nearly the wreck we might have expected. Josephine hugs Dr. Bennett and shakes hands with his WIFE. The service is crowded, more than 200 people, many more than expected. As his mother talks to a WELL-WISHER, Will looks left to see an Oldsmobile parking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON the license plates. Missouri. The passenger side opens, but the man who steps out is barely visible over the door. He shuts it to reveal himself to be 70. It's Amos Calloway. Will doesn't recognize him. The Driver climbs out, a size 15 foot on the gravel. We TILT UP to see this man is huge. This man is KARL, now 55. He's not 12 feet tall, but at least six-eight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON Will, bewildered to see that this man really exists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the service gets ready to begin, Will guides his mother to a seat near the grave. Sitting beside Will, Josephine spots a stunning ASIAN WOMAN (50) behind them. A beat later, an identical face with glasses peers out -- the woman's twin sister. It's PING and JING. Josephine almost GASPS. She elbows Will, who turns to look. From this angle the sisters seem conjoined, but then Jing steps forward. They're really two separate people. A sea of familiar faces, all of them aged through the years: BEAMEN, NORTHER WINSLOW, the MAYOR, and ZACKY PRICE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: [LATER] After the service, we see the crowd gathered in small groups. By the LAUGHTER and hand gestures, we can see they're telling stories. They're telling Edward's stories. We find Will watching them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will joins in, laughing. We slowly CIRCLE BEHIND a monument, letting it black out the screen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Have you ever heard a joke so many times you've forgotten why it's funny? But then you hear it again and suddenly it's new. You remember why you loved it in the first place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: [SUMMER] Will sits on the porch with Sandra and Josephine, watching his SON play in the pool with two NEIGHBOR KIDS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will smiles as his son continues the tale, which FADES. Sandra takes Will's hand in hers, just listening.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to the other boys) So he said he'd fight the giant who was fifteen feet tall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling over) Dad, that's right, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See. So he was a giant but my grampa was going to fight him because he wasn't afraid of anything because he'd seen how he was going to die in this old lady's glass eye...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) That was my father's final joke I guess. A man tells his stories so many times he becomes the stories. They live on after him.
dialogue.name: dialogue
